Three-Module Technical Skills Program

Goal: To align and fit in well with this training structure -> 



Capacity strengthening and training courses under BEIT (3.2 and 3.3)
Capacity strengthening of Business Support Organizations to develop sustainable training capacity (ToT approach): Engineering Union, Vocational Training Center, Mosul Space
BEIT-C-5) Heritage design and sustainable architecture for young graduates and engineers (short module)
BEIT-C-4) Starting up and managing a green business for young graduates and engineers (short module) – 3 options: focus solar, focus insulation, general
BEIT-C-3 Energy auditing and climate adaptation residential check up for engineers (short module)
BA/MA/PhD/Engineers - Male/Female- Want to start a business or become employees
Young graduates (Under 35 - Grade 12) – Male/Female - Unemployed, want to start a business or become employees
BEIT-C-2) Residential building insulation and cool roofing installation skills-150 hours of training /50% classroom -50% on the job apprenticeship
BEIT-C-1) Solar panel installation and maintenance skills - 150 hours of training /50% classroom -50% on the job apprenticeship
Informal construction workers (no formal training, literate, grade 7-9)- Male/Female - Are currently delivering construction services as a job/business
Targeted audience and minimum requirements

Daily Rhythm (3-Block Method) Standard For All Modules
Start with a framing (15 min) – 
	Today’s learning objective, customer story & goals.
Day | Learn | Apply | Sell

Learn (45-60 min) – Share core knowledge for the day + failure photos,learn from the trainers lived experience in the field, ask, how would you solve….
Apply (hands on experience) (90 min) – hands-on stations (rotate every 30 min).
Sell (60+ min) - Small group application and practice, dialog, role play, business models, ROI calculations, etc…
End with a reflection & assessment (45 min) - Q/A and streamlined method for assessing progress named sticky-note wall; trainer tweaks next day.

Pedagogical Philosophy:
70% Hands-on, 30% Theory - Always touch before talk
Problem-First Learning - Start each day with a real challenge, end with a solution
Continuous Case Study - One project evolves through the entire module, design and model a project to be applied. Likely to be the participants own family home.
Feedback Loop - Daily sticky note reflections for assessment and data collection
Mistake-Based Learning - Expert-identified failures drive curriculum content
Stakeholder Development & Insights for Curriculum
Expert Interviews - So far the Solar has the most depth, continuing to interview and develop content for architecture and insulation:
7 Solar Experts
7 Architecture Experts
4 Insulation Experts
Daily Structure Clarity:
Thematic Knowledge: Solar principles, R values, green home interventions…)
Practical Knowledge: Develop a case study for your own home / neighbor / family over the course of the entire week. Focus on a case that you may be able to apply something on before the optional day six next week!
Business: 
1. ROI: Learn how to build ROI models and sales engineering techniques
2. Business Modeling: Investment requirements, possibility profitability, etc  to help people imagining what it might be like to

Supplier Partnerships & Discount Scheme
To make sure trainees can turn new skills into income immediately, BEIT has secured partner offers with local suppliers.
Item
Details
Partner companies (confirmed)
• Mohammed Qatan Solar Co. (solar hardware) 
• Dr Nasih Green Materials (insulation & coatings) 
• Al-Hadbaa Building Supply (tools & fixings)
Offer 1 – “Install first, pay later”
Supplier delivers materials for a graduate’s first customer job. Graduate (or customer) pays the supplier only after the installation is inspected and invoiced.
Offer 2 – Bulk-buy after graduation
Graduates pool their orders; BEIT negotiates wholesale prices. Materials are stored at Mosul Space’s tool-library room and checked out as needed.
Who qualifies
Trainees who ① complete the 5-day module and ② pass the optional Day-6 field verification.
Simple process
1. Graduate fills in a one-page “Material Request” form.
2. Trainer signs off.
3. Supplier schedules delivery within 48 h.
4. Trainer (or partner company) inspects the job and submits a photo log.
BEIT support roles
• Training coordinator keeps records and links graduates to suppliers. 
• Suppliers invoice BEIT quarterly for deferred-payment jobs (max 60 days).
Pilot timeline
Pilot runs immediately after each module, with a joint review at the 3-month alumni meetup.


Post-Course Design Competition Brief
This competition lets graduates (and earlier alumni) showcase heritage-inspired, climate-smart designs that fit Mosul’s current housing reality.
Element
Requirement
Challenge title
“150 m² Heritage-Inspired Green Home for a Young Mosul Family”
Standard persona
• Plot: 150 m² inherited lot in East Mosul 
• Owner: 30-year-old dentist, spouse, two children 
• Budget cap: 100 M IQD (≈ USD 75 k)
Design objectives
1. ≥ 25 % energy-use reduction vs. typical build.
2. Indoor summer attic temp max 32 °C.
3. Courtyard or greenery-based shading strategy.
4. Façade respects Maslawi architectural language.
Submission package
• Site plan & one floor plan (PDF).
• One cross-section & façade rendering.
• Bill-of-materials + cost sheet.
• ≤ 300-word ROI & comfort summary.
Evaluation rubric (100 pts)
Thermal performance 30 pts 
• Cost realism 25 
• Heritage aesthetics 15 
• Greenery & shading 15 
• Presentation clarity 15
Timeline
Launch on Day 5 of Module 3. Submissions are due 4 weeks later. Public jury & awards at the following monthly meetup.
Prizes
1st Place – IR camera loan plus feature on BEIT website 
• 2nd/3rd – Tool-library vouchers and supplier-discount certificates.
Eligibility
Open to all Module 3 graduates and any alumni of Modules 1–2 who wish to enter.

is there any available research on the impact of solar panels covering a rooftop and the change in rooftop temperature because it shades it?

Yes, research indicates that installing solar photovoltaic (PV) panels on rooftops can significantly reduce roof surface temperatures by providing shade, which in turn lowers indoor cooling demands.

### Key Findings:

- **Roof Temperature Reduction**: A study from the University of California, San Diego, found that solar panels can reduce the amount of heat reaching the roof by up to 38%, keeping the building’s roof 5°C cooler than portions exposed to direct sunlight. citeturn0search10

- **Cooling Energy Savings**: In tropical and subtropical climates, roof-mounted PV systems have been shown to reduce cooling loads by shading the roof surface from direct solar radiation. For instance, in an Indian city, cooling products provided savings of up to 34.8%, with roof cooling loads falling from 73% to 90% after PV installation. citeturn0search3

- **Urban Heat Island Mitigation**: Large-scale deployment of rooftop PV panels can influence local microclimates. In some cases, studies have observed that PV panels on urban rooftops might elevate the temperature at the building scale, causing discomfort in outdoor urban environments. citeturn0search2

### Practical Implications:

- **Enhanced Building Comfort**: By shading the roof, solar panels reduce the heat transferred into the building, leading to cooler indoor temperatures and increased occupant comfort.

- **Energy Efficiency**: The reduction in roof temperature decreases the need for air conditioning, leading to energy savings and lower utility bills.

- **Extended Roof Lifespan**: Shading from solar panels can protect roofing materials from UV radiation and thermal degradation, potentially extending the roof's lifespan.

Incorporating these findings into building design and energy planning can enhance sustainability and occupant comfort, especially in hot climates like Mosul's.
